1.0  Tosco Santa Maria Facility RMP: Executive Summary

The United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) requires companies such as Tosco Refining Co. (Tosco) to submit a Risk Management Plan (RMP) for any processes containing regulated substances above a threshold quantity (TQ) this applies to the Santa Maria Facility.  The Santa Maria Facility handles hazardous materials onsite, and recognizes a responsibility to safely operate the facility in order to protect the surrounding community, employees, and the environment.  The Facility has taken a proactive stance to promote the overall safe operation of the processes, with programs to prevent accidents from occurring, planning for emergencies, and maintaining the equipment needed if an emergency does occur.  The RMP formalizes existing programs and procedures so that these programs may be reviewed more efficiently.

The Santa Maria Facility processes oil into intermediate products for further processing at other locations to produce gasoline.  The Facility receives oil from many sources via pipeline, stores it in tanks onsite, and processes the oil into products to be shipped elsewhere by pipeline, railcar, and truck.  The Refining process separates the crude oil into four products: gas oil, naphtha (pressure distillate), sulfur, and coke (solid carbon based material).  The sulfur is generated because oil contains significant quantities of sulfur that must be removed to produce gasoline.  The gas oil and naphtha products are also stored in the Facility's Storage Tanks prior to shipping by pipeline, while the solid sulfur and solid coke are shipped offsite by truck or railcar.  The Facility also has the utility and support systems required to provide for safe operation of the plant, including a power generation Facility to make use of gas generated in the Refining Process.

The RMP consists of three parts required for submittal:
7 RMP Executive Summary
7 Hazard Assessment
7 RMP Data Elements

The RMP effort at

the Facility was divided into three phases.  First, the Facility determined which processes are covered by the EPA Regulation.  The results of this study are documented in the report titled "Phase I: Inventory Determination." Phase I measured the quantities of regulated substances to determine which processes are subject to EPA RMP.  Next, the Facility conducted the required Hazard Assessment as defined by the regulation.  The Hazard Assessment modeled accidental release scenarios that provided Tosco insight about the potential for onsite processes to affect the surrounding community and the environment.  A summary of the Hazard Assessment is provided in Section 2.  Finally, Phase III of the RMP effort is provided in this document.  It contains the Executive Summary of the overall RMP effort at the Facility and a description of the Management Systems in place to implement and maintain the Facility's risk management measures.

The Executive Summary, Data Elements and Hazard Assessment Results are submitted to the Federal EPA as part of its Risk Management Plan.

2.0  Tosco Santa Maria Facility Hazard Assessment Results

2.1 Offsite Consequence Analysis (OCA) Summary
The objectives of this hazard assessment are twofold: (1) satisfy the requirements of the EPA RMP Regulation and (2) provide OCA information that will help local emergency planning officials improve community emergency response in the event of an accidental release at the refinery.

The facility is presenting a Worst Case Scenario (WCS) to represent all f

lammable substances in covered processes.

EPA RMP requires an offsite consequence analysis for potential releases of flammable materials.  In modeling flammable materials, the stationary source is required to present distances to endpoints resulting from any of the following:
7 Explosion: Overpressure of 1 psig.
7 Radiant Heat/Fire: Radiant heat of 5 kW/m2 for 40 seconds.
7 Lower Flammability Limit: a lower flammability limit as provided in NFPA documents or other generally recognized sources.

Note:  There are no toxic release scenarios because the facility does not contain any toxic substances in quantities that exceed the Federal TQ.                                                                                                       

The flammable WCS was calculated to an overpressure of 1 psig using the release parameters set forth by the EPA for a Vapor Cloud Explosion.  The endpoint distance was determined to not impact offsite receptors. No mitigation measures were considered in the flammable WCS analysis.  EPA requires facilities to present Worst Case Scenarios regardless of site conditions or administrative and actual mitigation measures already in place at the facility.

2.2 Five Year Accident History

The EPA RMP rule requires facilities to compile a Five-Year Accident History for all RMP regulated substances in covered processes at the Facility.  The Facility documents and tracks all incidents and near misses that occur within the Facility.  This incident database served as the basis for the Five-Year Accident History presented here.
EPA RMP requires facilities to report any incident from a covered process involving a regulated substance and resulting in any of the following:
7 Onsite deaths, injuries, or significant property damage
7 Offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, evacuations, sheltering-in-place, or environmental damage

The facility did not experience any incidents in the past five years that qualify for reporting in the five year accid

ent history by the above criteria.

3.0 Tosco Santa Maria Facility Prevention Program

The following is a summary of the general accident prevention program in place at the Santa Maria Facility.  Because processes at the Facility that are regulated by the EPA RMP regulation are also subject to the Cal-OSHA PSM standard, this summary addresses each of the Cal-OSHA PSM elements and describes the management system in place to implement the accident prevention program.  Each section below contains a brief summary of the prevention program elements and the department responsible for implementation.  Each summary also designates the responsible party for each element.

3.1 Employee Participation
The Santa Maria Facility encourages employees to participate in all facets of process safety management and accident prevention.  The program actively involves employees in all parts of the PSM, Risk Management, and Loss Control Programs.  Examples of employee participation include the following:
7 Introductory and refresher training for all Facility personnel regarding the hazards of the process and process safety management
7 Operator preparation and annual review of written operating procedures 
7 Operations participation in various Process Hazard Analyses at the Facility
7 Job-specific training programs for all employees, including safe work practices
7 Regular Safety Meetings on pertinent topics at the Facility
7 Operations and Maintenance participation in incident investigations
7 "Triad" reviews of all management of change projects with representatives from Technical Services, Operations, and Maintenance
7 A unified Emergency Response Program and inclusion of various personnel in drills
All PSM and RMP related documents are available to personnel through the Facility's computer network and through document copies throughout the Facility.  Specific ways that employees can be involved in the accident prevention program are documented in the PSM Program and Loss Control Proced

ures.  The Facility also utilizes its Joint Labor-Management Health and Safety Committee to participate in the requirements outlined by PSM.
The Health, Safety, Security, & Emergency Response (HSS&ER) Department is responsible for administering the Employee Participation portion of the Prevention Program.

3.2 Process Safety Information
The Santa Maria Facility keeps all technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the processes.  The Facility utilizes a computer-based document manager known as the LiNX database to give personnel access to documentation required for PSM.  The LiNX system operates through the Facility's computer network and is accessible from many computer terminals throughout the Facility.  In addition to the LiNX system, the Facility maintains paper copies of all design data sheets, MSDS process hazard analyses, operating procedures, and emergency response procedures at various locations throughout the Facility.  It is the Facility's goal to make the process safety information easily accessible to all personnel as required by PSM and RMP.  All personnel have been trained about the basics of navigating the LiNX system.
Chemical-specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in material safety data sheets (MSDS).  MSDS are available on the LiNX system and in MSDS manuals in the HSS&ER Department.
The Facility also maintains numerous technical documents that provide information about the design and construction of process equipment.  This information includes materials of construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, electrical rating of equipment, etc.  This information, in combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provides a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and Facility changes to ensure that safety features in the process are not compromised.
The LiNX system

is kept up to date by the Facility computer department and by the Operations Department.  All process safety information is updated regularly as part of the MOC process, and procedures are updated yearly as part of the procedure review.  All process drawings are maintained by the drafting department and on the computer network.  All process safety information is made available for any process hazard analysis conducted at the Facility.
The Technical Services and Operations Departments are responsible for implementing the Process Safety Information portion of the Prevention Program.

3.3 Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)
The Santa Maria Facility has a comprehensive program to help ensure that hazards associated with the various processes are identified and controlled.  Within this program, each Facility unit is systematically examined to identify hazards and ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage these hazards.  The PHA team identifies and evaluates hazards of the process as well as accident prevention and mitigation measures, and makes suggestions for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures when the team believes such measures are necessary.
The Santa Maria Facility primarily uses the hazard and operability (HAZOP) analysis technique to perform these evaluations.  HAZOP analysis is recognized as one of the most systematic and thorough hazard evaluation techniques.  Other techniques utilized less frequently are What-If/Checklist Analysis and Failure Modes & Effects Analysis (FMEA).
The PHAs are conducted using a team of people who have operating and engineering experience.  Typically, the HAZOP team consists of a Technical Services Representative, an Operations Representative, and someone knowledgeable in the PHA Methodology.  Other team members are included as needed.  These members may include maintenance, project managers, and contractors.  
The PHA team findings are reviewed and tracked using the HAZOP Recommendation Tracking Procedure.  The ap

propriate Facility engineering and Operations personnel review the recommended changes from the HAZOP for their feasibility and impact.
The Facility revalidates the Unit HAZOPs every five years as required by EPA and Cal-OSHA.  The revalidation incorporates any changes in the unit during the time period and also reviews any incidents that occurred in the unit.  All Facility process units subject to Process Safety Management have a completed HAZOP Study.  The refinery PHA Coordinator maintains a list of the units and their respective revalidation dates.
The Technical Services Department has been trained to lead and document Facility PHAs.  For large Unit PHAs and Revalidation Studies, the Facility utilizes the services of a contractor to facilitate and scribe the process hazard analyses.  The Facility also utilizes a computer program (PHA-ProR) specifically programmed to document the process hazard analyses.  For each PHA, the Operations representative and other inexperienced HAZOP team members are given HAZOP introductory training and receive guidance from the HAZOP team leader of their PHA responsibilities.  All HAZOP documents are available for review on the LiNX system and from the PHA Coordinator.
The Technical Services Department is responsible for implementing the Process Hazard Analysis portion of the Prevention Program.

3.4 Operating Procedures
The Santa Maria Facility maintains a complete set of written procedures for operations and maintenance that address all modes of process operations, including unit startup, normal operations, shutdown, and emergency shutdown.  Operating procedures serve as a basis for training and operation of the units, to ensure that the process is operated consistently and safely by all personnel.  As part of Operations Administration Procedure, the Facility reviews and updates the procedures to ensure that they are accurate and reflect the current state of operation and process improvement.  The annual procedure reviews address a

nnel must proceed through a structured, performance-based training system prior to operating the units.  After qualification, operators continue learning other units to become more versatile and aware of other processes at the Facility.  The training program consists of the following steps:
7 Initial Training
7 Initial Training Testing
7 Job Specific Training/MTS Training Manual
7 Job Specific On-The-Job Training Equipment Check-off
7 Job Specific Written/Practical Demonstration Test
7 Job Specific Refresher Training
Operators must pass both the Qualification Test and Performance Test when qualifying in a unit.  The Qualification Test consists of a written test pertaining to the process, procedures, health hazards, and safety on the job.  The Performance Test is a field test administered to determine if an employee can transfer written knowledge acquired to the actual hands-on task in the field.  All tests and training materials are maintained in personnel files.  Prior to assignment at a unit, management and the operator's supervisor must sign off that the affected operator is prepared to work the unit by reviewing with the operator both the written and in-the-field tests.  A general outline for initial and refresher training for personnel includes:
I. An overview of the process (job specific)
II. Operating procedures applicable to each job
III. Steps for each operating phase including:
7 Initial Startup
7 Normal Operation
7 Temporary Operation
7 Emergency Operation
7 Emergency Shutdown
7 Normal Shutdown 
7 Startup following a turnaround
7 Startup following an emergency shutdown
IV. Operating limits and consequences of deviation
V. Safety and Health considerations
VI. Safety Systems and their functions
Personnel may also take part in the Facility's Emergency Response Team by completing specific training and testing.  The Facility utilizes trained onsite personnel to respond in case of emergency.
The Operations and Maintenance Departments are responsible for impleme

t a minimum:
7 Current operating practices, including changes that result from changes in process chemicals, technology and equipment, and changes to facilities.
7 Operating limits: consequences of process deviation and steps necessary to avoid deviation.
7 Safety and health considerations, including:
- properties of, and hazards presented by, chemicals in the process
- precautions necessary to prevent exposure, including personal protective equipment, engineering controls, and administrative controls
- quality control of raw materials and control of hazardous chemical inventory
- special or unique hazards
- safety systems and their functions
7 Hazards control during operation, including lockout/tagout, hot work, confined space entry, and opening process equipment or piping.
The Santa Maria Facility Management of Change program also includes a provision to ensure that any procedures modified by changes in the process are completed prior to implementation of the change.  All Operating Personnel are notified any time a new procedure is issued or an existing procedure is modified.  Complete sets of procedures are available to all Facility personnel in both paper copies at various points within the Facility and on the LiNX database.
The Operations Department is responsible for implementing the Operating Procedures portion of the Prevention Program.

3.5 Training
The Facility believes that good operators help ensure safe, planned operations of the process units.  The Facility's training program requires employees to qualify in a process unit prior to being assigned for operation, to understand the nature and causes of problems arising from process operation, and to elevate their awareness with respect to hazards of operating the processes.  Each employee assigned to a process unit proceeds sequentially through a planned training program to familiarize new personnel with unit operations.  Personnel are not assigned to work jobs that they are unqualified to perform. 
Perso

nting the Operator Training portion of the Prevention Program.

3.6 Contractors
The Santa Maria Facility employs numerous contractors to perform unit maintenance and construction.  Therefore, contractors must adhere to similar or identical safety standards as Facility personnel.
The Facility outlines safety and training programs for contractors.  Contractors are trained by onsite personnel about the hazards of the process, safety procedures and equipment requirements, and the emergency response procedure onsite prior to commencement of work.  All contractors performing operations at the Facility must complete the Facility Safety Orientation Program.  The Safety Orientation Program includes Rules of Conduct, Emergency Procedures, HazCom, PSM, Hearing Conservation, TSCA, and RCRA topics, which are required by Tosco's Contractor Standard.  Contractors must also provide basic safety training to their own employees as required by State and Federal Regulations.  Contractors are advised of Tosco's communication program.
The Facility screens contractors' own safety programs and performance prior to awarding of contracts at the Facility.  Contractors must be approved via a qualification procedure.  The review process ensures the Facility's compliance to corporate standards and to regulatory requirements for employing the services of contractors.  Information regarding a Contractor's area of expertise, financial stability, safety history, safety and health policies and programs, employee training, regulatory compliance, insurance coverage and other areas of interest to the Facility are solicited prior to starting work at the Facility.
Facility personnel periodically monitor contractor performance to ensure that contractors are fulfilling their conduct, training, and safety obligations.
The Maintenance Department is responsible for implementing the Contractors portion of the Prevention Program.

3.7 Pre-Startup Safety Reviews (PSSRs)
The Santa Maria Facility conducts a PSSR fo

r any new Facility or Facility modification that requires a change in the process safety information.  The purpose of the PSSR is to ensure that safety features, procedures, personnel, and equipment are appropriately prepared for startup prior to placing the equipment into service.  This review provides one additional check to make sure construction is in accordance with the design specifications and that all supporting systems are operationally ready.  The PSSR is conducted as part of the Facility Management of Change procedure just prior to startup and final acceptance of the project. Department Supervisors review and approve their department checklists to ensure that the project is safe and operable.  Tech Services and Operations and Maintenance Department Supervisors all review and sign off on their respective checklists prior to startup.
The Technical Services Department is responsible for implementing the Pre-Startup Safety Review portion of the Prevention Program.

3.8 Mechanical Integrity
The Santa Maria Facility has well-established practices and procedures to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps and compressors, and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition.  The main parts of the program are outlined below.  In combination, these activities form a system that maintains the mechanical integrity of the process equipment.

Program Section            Purpose
Code Compliance            Ensuring that all process equipment is designed with the appropriate codes         
                           and industry standards
Training                   Ensuring that inspectors and operators are inspecting properly and are alert to 
                           abnormal conditions and corrosion/wear
Inspection Procedures      Ensuring that inspections are consistent throughout the Facility and that all 
                           inspections are conducted safely
Inspection Schedules       Ensuring that inspecti

ons are conducted as frequently as required by code or by 
                           equipment service/life time, and providing a baseline for corrosion rates.
Quality Assurance          Ensuring that all changes and equipment replacements/upgrades are compliant with 
                           code requirements and meet design specifications prior to startup

The mechanical integrity program is maintained by nearly all Facility departments.  Each department has responsibilities for different program aspects.  The equipment type and primary responsibility are outlined below.

Equipment Type                             Primary Responsibility
Pressure Vessels                           Inspection Department
Heat Exchangers                            Inspection Department
Fired Heaters & Boilers                    Inspection Department
Piping & Fittings                          Inspection Department
Pressure Relief Devices                    Inspection Department
Storage Tanks                              Inspection Department
Rotating Equipment                         Maintenance
Valves                                     Maintenance
Control Valves                             Maintenance
Instrumentation                            Maintenance
Electrical Equipment                       Maintenance
Structures/Foundations                     Technical Services
Hoists/Lifts/Materials Handling            Maintenance
Fire Protection Systems                    HSS&ER 

The program covers equipment used to process, control, and store hazardous chemicals and assigns responsibility for the inspection and testing of such equipment.  Written procedures help ensure that work is performed in a consistent manner and provide a basis for training.  Inspections and tests are performed to help ensure that equipment functions as intended, and to verify that equipment is within acceptable limits (e.g., adequate wall thickness for pressure vessels).  If a deficiency is identified, employees

will correct the deficiency before placing the equipment back into service (if possible), or an MOC team will review the use of the equipment and determine what actions are necessary to ensure the safe operation of the equipment.
The Santa Maria Facility incorporates quality assurance measures into equipment purchases and repairs.  This helps ensure that new equipment is suitable for its intended use, and that proper materials and spare parts are used when repairs are made.  Quality assurance is determined as part of the Management of Change Program.
The Technical Services Department is responsible for implementing the Mechanical Integrity portion of the Prevention Program.

3.9 Safe Work Practices
Tosco Santa Maria Facility provides a safe and healthful work place for the workers at the Facility, contractors, visitors, and the community surrounding the Facility.  Safe work practices are in place to ensure that common hazardous activities are conducted safely and routinely.  These procedures (and others), along with training of affected personnel and contractors, form a system to help ensure that operations and maintenance activities are performed safely.  Examples of standard safe work practices at the Santa Maria Facility include: 
7 Tracking and control of the entry/presence/exit of personnel into and out of the Facility
7 A hazardous energy procedure to ensure isolation of energy sources for equipment undergoing maintenance
7 A procedure for safe removal of hazardous materials before process piping or equipment is opened
7 A permit and procedure to control spark producing activities (i.e., hot work)
7 A permit and procedure to ensure that adequate precautions are in place before entry into a confined space
In addition to the Safe Work Practices outlined above, the Santa Maria Facility conducts regular Physical Conditions Inspections to ensure compliance with Federal, State, and local regulations, and Company loss control requirements.  The intent of the inspect

ions is to:
7 Determine the effectiveness of the Facility's loss control system
7 Establish a level of compliance
7 Identify hazards and substandard conditions/practices for correction
7 Give recognition for exceptional compliance
Specific physical conditions inspections are conducted of each processing unit, storage and tankage areas, maintenance facilities, warehouse, laboratory, office buildings, and contractor work sites.
The HSS&ER Department administers the Safe Work Practices portion of the Prevention Program.

3.10 Management of Change
The Santa Maria Facility has a comprehensive system to manage changes to processes.  The Management of Change procedure has been implemented in order to ensure that all equipment and installations are built in a manner that ensures safety and operability.  Whenever equipment or installations are modified, new facilities are added or process changes are necessary, a review by appropriate engineering, Operations, Maintenance, safety, and environmental personnel is conducted.  For all changes, a Technical Services Work Request (TSWR) is submitted to management, reviewed, and forwarded to the TSWR Triad for review.  The Triad consists of Operations, Maintenance, and Technical Services Representatives.  This system requires that changes to items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology (including process operating conditions), procedures, and other Facility changes be properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented.
Changes are reviewed to:
7 ensure that adequate controls are in place to manage any new hazards, and
7 verify that existing controls have not been compromised by the change.
Projects proceed from the Triad through a planned sequence of signoffs designed to ensure that all parties are aware of the changes being implemented.  Details of the MOC Process Flow are available in Section 9 of the Loss Control Manual.  Affected process safety information, including chemical hazard information, process operating

limits, and equipment information, as well as procedures, is updated to incorporate these changes.  In addition, operating and maintenance personnel are provided any necessary training on the change.  Prior to startup, the MOC procedure requires a Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR) described above.
The Technical Services Department is responsible for implementing the Management of Change portion of the Prevention Program.

3.11 Incident Investigation
The Santa Maria Facility promptly investigates all incidents that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire/explosion, toxic gas release, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury.  Notification of incidents is made immediately so appropriate action can be taken and investigations can be initiated.  Investigation activities are directed toward defining the facts and circumstances related to the event, determining the causes, and developing corrective measures.  The final resolution of each finding or recommendation is documented, and the investigation results are reviewed with all employees (including contractors) who could be affected by the findings.
Investigations of serious incidents include Management, Engineering, Operations, and HSS&ER staff as appropriate.  Incident investigation reports are retained for at least five years so that the reports can be reviewed during future process hazard analyses.  Forms and investigation specifics are available in Section 5 of the Loss Control Manual.
The HSS&ER Department is responsible for implementing the Incident Investigation portion of the Prevention Program.

3.12 Compliance Audits
To help ensure that the accident prevention program is functioning properly, the Santa Maria Facility periodically conducts an audit to determine whether the procedures and practices required by the accident prevention program are being implemented.
Compliance audits currently are conducted for PSM at least every three years.  The RMP Program and Hazard Asses

sment will now be included in the triennial audit.
The Audit is typically broken down into three phases.  Phase I involves a question and answer session with various Facility personnel to determine regulatory compliance. Phase II involves performing spot verifications to confirm that programs meet the intent of the standards.  Phase III consists of a series of interview questions with various employee groups to gauge the effectiveness of the programs.
The audit findings are forwarded to appropriate Facility personnel for tracking and resolution.  The final resolution of each finding is documented, and the two most recent audit reports are retained.
The HSS&ER Department is responsible for implementing the Compliance Audit portion of the Prevention Program.

3.13 Chemical Specific Prevention Steps
The processes at the Santa Maria Facility have hazards that must be managed to ensure continued safe operation.  The accident prevention program summarized previously is applied to the Program 3 process at the Facility.  Collectively, these prevention program activities help prevent potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures and human errors.
Some of the administrative programs to prevent, detect or mitigate an incident at the Facility are presented above.  Specific safety equipment and procedures, known as safeguards, are in place at the Facility.  These safeguards are listed as part of the Process Hazard Analyses, process safety information, and in the operating procedures.  Some examples of safeguards are presented below.
Release Detection
7 Hydrogen Sulfide detectors with alarms
7 Facility alarm system to notify personnel in case of emergency
Release Containment/Control
7 Process relief valves to protect all pressure vessels
7 Operating materials recovery system with process flare to incinerate excess materials from the process
7 Manual and automatic valves to permit isolation of the process
7 Automated shutdown systems for specific process

parameters
7 "Fail-Safe" valves to isolate equipment in case of unplanned events such as power failures and earthquakes
7 Containment around all tanks and process areas to contain liquid materials
7 Backup power supply for critical process equipment
7 Tank vapor recovery system to contain hazardous tank vapors
Release Mitigation
7 Fire suppression and extinguishing systems
7 Deluge system for specific equipment
7 Trained emergency response personnel
7 Personal protective equipment (e.g., protective clothing, self-contained breathing apparatus)
7 Blast-resistant buildings to help protect control systems and personnel
7 Backup fire protection equipment

4.0 Emergency Response Program Summary

The Tosco Santa Maria Facility has adopted the Incident Command System to ensure a safe and effective response to Facility emergencies.  The Facility is prepared to respond to all emergencies internally, with support from outside authorities if needed.  The Facility's Emergency Response Team (ERT), consisting of at least two Supervisory personnel and four operators, responds to all Facility emergency incidents.  If Initial Response personnel cannot mitigate the incident, an Advanced Response is implemented utilizing additional Facility personnel and external assistance. Emergencies requiring response by the Facility include:
7 Fire or potential fire
7 Gas or Oil Release
7 Serious injury/illness
7 Release of toxic chemicals
7 Emergency requiring search and rescue

The Facility has prepared for emergencies onsite through a variety of training and administrative planning segments.  As part of the Pre-Emergency Planning Program the Facility has provided:
7 Personnel training for fire fighting, hazard communication, incident command, first aid/CPR, SCBA, and       hazardous waste worker training to prevent and respond to emergencies.
7 Established evacuation routes and safe areas for all Facility personnel, visitors and contractors, as well as attendance and check in procedures.
7 Ext

ernal assistance availability of local fire and rescue, medical, and environmental clean-up organizations to provide assistance during advanced responses.
7 Emergency equipment and supplies maintained throughout the Facility to respond to anticipated incidents.
7 Communications networks, including back-up systems established for internal and external communications.
7 Pre-emergency plans, including ongoing hazard specific pre-fire plans, developed to provide guidance in responding to emergencies in an organized and effective manner to protect onsite personnel, surrounding communities, and the environment.
7 Emergency response drills scheduled on a monthly basis to ensure efficient response by onsite personnel.

The Santa Maria Facility supplies Emergency Response Team members with respiratory protection and personal protective clothing for use while responding to emergencies; this equipment is designed to allow the ERT to work safely during an emergency.  A variety of fire fighting and spill containment materials are located at the Facility or stationed nearby for response to emergencies.  All equipment is inspected, maintained, and replaced regularly to ensure dependable performance.

The Facility uses five different systems to disseminate emergency instructions and information within the Facility.  Those systems include:
7 Plant Alarms (Facility General Alarm, Sulfur Plant Alarm, H2S Gas Release Alarm, Evacuation Alarm)
7 Emergency Public Address System
7 Internal Portable Radio Network 
7 Plant and External Telephones
7 Pagers

The Facility's initial response to an emergency is essential to successfully control an incident without the need for advanced response.  By controlling an incident during initial response the Facility reduces the risk to the initial responders, ERT, operating personnel, the public, and the environment.  The Facility has predefined emergency response responsibilities which onsite personnel fill in case of an emergency.  Those positions inc

lude:

Planning Chief                           Planning Support Team
Initial Responder                        Logistics Chief
Incident Commander (IC)                  Liaison Officer
Safety Officer (SO)                      Staging Officer
Emergency Response Team (ERT)            Public Information Officer
Operations Chief                         Finance Chief
Command Staff Coordinator                Communications Officer

When the Incident Commander believes that additional Tosco emergency response personnel are required to handle an emergency, he/she will contact the Communications Officer to contact standby shift personnel and will notify the Main Gate Security Officer to activate the pager callout.  The Incident Commander makes the determination when external assistance or reporting is required.  The Facility may request assistance from any of the following agencies:
 
California Department of Forestry,  Pacific Gas & Electric, Arroyo Grande Hospital, Union Pacific Railroad
California Highway Patrol, San Luis Obispo County Emergency Services, San Luis Obispo County Sheriff, California Office of Emergency Services, Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), National Response Center.

External assistance will normally be called only during advanced emergencies at the instruction of the Incident Commander.  The Facility has around-the-clock communications capability with appropriate officials and emergency response organizations.  This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident.  Emergency situations that may endanger human heath or the environment outside the Facility will be reported to the Local Emergency Services Organization (San Luis Obispo County Emergency Services).  They, in turn, may notify appropriate State and local response organizations to respond to the scene and lead offsite evacuation efforts.

In the event of an uncontrolled release of potentially toxic chemicals or fl

ammable materials, the Facility will perform emergency exposure air monitoring with the emergency response efforts.  This monitoring will be conducted primarily to help quantify atmospheric exposures to the community and to help identify protection requirements.  

The Facility is also prepared to manage offsite incidents potentially affecting the Facility.  The nature of the emergency shall dictate the degree of response: Minimal, Moderate, or Advanced.  The responses are outlined below:
7 Minimal Response: incident requires minimal onsite response, typically security
7 Moderate Response: incident requires resources such as security, EMT personnel, and ambulance or law enforcement notification
7 Advanced Response: incident such as wildland fire, flood or earthquake, requiring an advanced response of the ICS System, potentially using outside resources like the California Department of Forestry, California Highway Patrol, local and county fire and paramedic resources, and law enforcement

A copy of the Facility's Emergency Response Plan is provided to the local emergency response agencies.  The plan provides detailed information on the Facility's emergency response organization, procedures and resources.  Facility emergency response personnel periodically meet with local agency representatives to discuss response capabilities and to look for new ways to improve overall emergency response preparedness.
